Severity appears mild to moderate given the limited symptoms and absence of systemic illness, but the guarded communication indicates possible underreporting of severity. Urgency is priority to prevent potential complications and transmission. Differential diagnoses such as gonorrhea, chlamydia, or other STI-related proctitis remain relevant until confirmed. Immediate treatment should target likely pathogens, pending test results; further, symptomatic relief and preventive counseling are essential. Monitoring and follow-up are crucial to assess treatment response and adjust management accordingly.

Short-term goals (1-4 weeks) focus on symptom resolution, laboratory confirmation, and reducing transmission risk. Long-term objectives (3-6 months) include management of recurrent herpes episodes if needed, counseling for safe sex, and ongoing monitoring for other STIs.
